description:
Please complete this survey by Learning Lab 2 (Solving Complex Problems). You will receive 100 points for completing the survey and 0 points if you do not complete on time. There is no rubric or re-submission for this assignment. 

Here is the link: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1l-ysn1ZzA8YA47m7RVSqSM0R_FxO83toBdD0r4N2nKE/viewform
name: Pre-course survey (GRADED ASSIGNMENT)

description:
Complete through page 7 of your personal roadmap using this Word template and submit here. 

Make sure you have included: 

  1. A personal vision statement: Ideally 15 words or less. You may want to practice writing your statement unhindered by word count and then work on making it concise. This will also be the headline for your roadmap.
  2. Your big goals for this year
  3. A career focus
  4. You plan to execute on those goals: Customize the action plan and make it work for you! 
  5. A focus on career aspirations
  6. Optional: Feel free to include personal and non-career aspirations (e.g., financial, spiritual, relational, health, family)

How you will be graded

PERSONAL ROADMAP RUBRIC

Skill: Set vision and goals

10 points 9 points 8 points 7 points
Exceeds Meets expectation Somewhat meets Developing
MY ROADMAP INCLUDES A CLEAR DESTINATION. 

All of the criteria in “meets” is true

AND

There is a clear through line across the hustle, vision, and goals

Personal roadmap is complete with a hustle, vision, and goals

AND

Vision statement is communicated clearly using 11-15 words AND is ambitious and motivating

AND

Goals are SMART (specific, measurable, ambitious, reasonable, and time-based)

Two of the three are true from the criteria in the “meets” column

 One or none of the three criteria are true from the “meets” column
MY ROADMAP INCLUDES A CLEAR PATH TO MY DESIRED DESTINATION.

All of the criteria in “meets” is true

AND

My immediate priorities and action steps create a clear path toward achieving short-term milestones and goals

Goals are broken down into achievable milestones that allow me to check for progress at logical points in the timeline

AND

I have a short-term plan that includes the immediate actions I need to take

One of the two criteria in “meets” is true

None of the criteria in “meets” is true
MY ROADMAP WILL HELP ME REACH MY CAREER GOALS.

All of the criteria in “meets” is true

AND

Includes consideration of network-building, career-related summer opportunities, major declaration, and/or college course selection (e.g., in goals and/or milestones)

Personal roadmap indicates a clear career focus (industry/sector and roles of interest)

AND

My vision, goals, and plan are inclusive of my career aspirations

One of the two criteria in “meets” is true

None of the criteria in “meets” is true
name: Your personal roadmap (GRADED ASSIGNMENT)

description:
Make any refinements to your draft resume that incorporates the feedback from your peers, lessons learned from the Learning Lab, and customizations for the specific role or opportunity. 

Please upload the link for the Fellowship or summer internship for which you are intending to apply (either now or in the future, depending on the date the application is due). 

How you will be graded

The following rubric will be used to assess your resume:

10 POINTS 9 POINTS 8 POINTS 7 POINTS
EXCEEDS MEETS EXPECTATION SOMEWHAT MEETS DEVELOPING
FORMAt

All of meets

AND

This resume fills the page but is not overcrowded.

This resume looks overcrowded

AND

There are no spelling errors and grammatical mistakes.

AND

It can be easily scanned for key insights

This resume looks overcrowded

AND

There are a few spelling errors and grammatical mistakes.

AND

It can be easily scanned for key insights

This resume is either one-half page or two to three pages long.

AND

The font is too big or may be hard to read.

AND

There is more white space than words on the page.

AND

There are multiple spelling and/or grammar errors
education

All of meets

AND

It highlights the most pertinent information and includes: institution and its location, graduation date, major, degree, GPA, study abroad (as appropriate), and any relevant course work

Information such as institution and its location, graduation date, and major are included, but degree is not listed.

AND

This section is well organized and there is no order to how information is formatted

Information such as institution and its location, graduation date, and major are included, but degree and GPA are not listed.

AND

This section is not well organized and there is no order to how information is formatted.

This section is missing the most crucial information. Institution is listed, but not its location and graduation date is missing.

AND

The major is included, but not degree.

AND

No GPA is stated
experience

All of meets

AND

Specific details and numbers are present to describe accomplishments

This section is well defined, and information relates to the intended career field.

AND

Strong action verbs used along with concrete details.

AND

Places of work, location, titles, and dates are included for each position.

AND

Specific details and numbers are missing describe accomplishments

Descriptions are not presented in bulleted lists that begin with strong action verbs.

AND

Specific details and numbers are missing describe accomplishments.

AND

Passive voice structure is used instead of active voice.

OR

Places of work are included for each position, but not locations, dates, and titles 

There is no order to the descriptions of each position.

AND

Descriptions are not detailed and don't illustrate the experience.

AND

No locations and dates of employment are listed
LEADERSHIP

All of meets

AND

This section lists clearly leadership skills and date of involvement

Organizations are listed, and Individual involvement in each, are described.

AND

This section is missing key information such as leaderships positions held or dates of involvement

This section is missing key information such as leaderships positions held or dates of involvement.

AND

Organizations are listed; the organization, not Individual involvement in each, are described

This section is missing—or contains very little—information.

AND

Organization titles or dates of involvement are not included, and there are no descriptions
 SKILLS AND INTERESTS
Skills and honors listed clearly with bulleted details provided Some events are listed, but not clear and missing gaps

Some events are listed, but not clear and missing gaps

OR

Information present does not relate to the role

 Does not include any skills, courses, experiences
name: Resume (GRADED ASSIGNMENT)

description:
This assignment is due by Learning Lab 2 (6:00pm, day of your assigned Learning Lab). Upload your action plan here. Remember when submitting your assignment to use the following naming convention: Firstname.Lastname_Assignmentname (E.g., Susie.Song_ActionPlan)

Again, feel free to use one of the sample action plans in this module as a template or create your own. The important thing is to critically think about what you need and how you will organize your plan to help you, and this may result in your own unique action plan format!

 

How you will be graded

ACTION PLAN RUBRIC

Skill: Manage time, priorities, and organizational systems

10 POINTS 9 POINTS 8 POINTS 7 POINTS
EXCEEDS MEETS EXPECTATION SOMEWHAT MEETS DEVELOPING
Action plan is oriented around priorities.
Priorities are clearly introduced and articulated and listed at the top of the document or presented in a way that is clearly pops or represents importance Priorities are clearly introduced and articulated somewhere in the action plan

Priorities are articulated but without a header to introduce them so it is up to the grader to guess that they are priorities

 Priorities are not introduced or articulated
Action plan demonstrates understanding that priorities are what are most critical and important and critical to accomplish.
No more than 3 priorities are listed No more than 5 priorities are listed No more than 7 priorities are listed 8 or more priorities are listed
Action plan reflects a system for tracking, listing, or categorizing what needs to get done.
Space is provided to record tasks that need to be completed and there is evidence of tracking, listing, and categorizing AND Includes next steps on Reflected Best Self exercise Space is provided to record tasks that need to be completed and there is evidence of 2 of the 3: tracking, listing, categorizing what needs to get done AND Includes next steps on Reflected Best Self exercise Space is provided to record tasks that need to be completed and there is evidence of 1 of the 3: tracking, listing, categorizing what needs to get done OR Does not include next steps on Reflected Best Self exercise 1 of the 2 is true: Space is not provided to record tasks OR Space is provided but it is unclear for what purpose it is used for AND Does not include next steps on Reflected Best Self exercise
OVERALL: Action plan is usable by others. I.e. If someone else had to execute on it, they would know what needs to get done and what needs to be prioritized.
Very true True Somewhat true Not true
name: Your action plan after peer feedback exchange (GRADED ASSIGNMENT)

description:
For full credit, you will need to:

  1. Complete the questions below.
  2. Submit a file upload of your final prototype - If it takes on a form other than paper, picture, or video, take a picture of it or find another creative way to submit.

Remember to use the following naming convention for your file upload: Firstname.Lastname_Assignmentname (E.g., Susie.Song_DreamJobPrototype)

Be ready to present your prototype during the next Learning Lab! We are excited to see what you came up with!

HOW YOU WILL BE GRADED

DESIGN THINKING RUBRIC

Skill: Design thinking

10 POINTS 9 POINTS 8 POINTS 7 POINTS
EXCEEDS MEETS EXPECTATION SOMEWHAT MEETS DEVELOPING
EMPATHIZE
Demonstrates evidence of understanding the client and his/her needs
AND Identifies why the client is affected by the problem and has a stake in the solution
AND 3 or more techniques were used to gather information about the user		 Demonstrates evidence of understanding the client and his/her needs
AND Identifies why the client is affected by the problem and has a stake in the solution
AND At least two techniques were used to gather information about the user

Demonstrates limited evidence of understanding the client and his/her needs
OR Identifies why the client is affected by the problem and has a stake in the solution
AND At least one technique was used to gather information about the user

 Demonstrates limited evidence of understanding the client and his/her needs
AND Does not identify why the client is affected by the problem and has a stake in the solution
OR does but conclusions may be influenced by personal bias
AND It is not clear what technique, if any, was used to gather information about the user
DEFINE
Defines the problem with a clear point of view (user, need, and insight) AND Problem statement is simple and gets to the root cause AND Develops “how might we” questions in preparation to ideate Defines the problem with a clear point of view (user, need and insight) AND Problem statement is simple AND Problem statement gets to the root cause Point of view is incomplete or inaccurate OR Problem statement is unclear OR too wordy AND It is unclear whether the problem statement addresses the root cause Point of view is incomplete or inaccurate AND Problem statement is unclear OR too wordy AND It is unclear whether the problem statement addresses the root cause
IDEATE
Demonstrates evidence of multiple rounds of brainstorming, adding “what if’s” or exploring more than one “how might we”
AND Brings in other students to participate in a collaborative brainstorming process		 Demonstrates evidence of multiple rounds of brainstorming, adding “what if’s” or exploring more than one “how might we” Demonstrates at least one round of brainstorming
OR limited idea generation		 Demonstrates no evidence of brainstorming
AND limited idea generation
PROTOTYPE
Prototypes relate to the problem statement
AND Student builds out three initial prototypes with clear 6 word headlines
AND A user can experience each prototype
AND Prototypes are distinctly different		 Prototypes are related to the problem statement
AND Student builds out three initial prototypes with clear 6 word headlines
AND A user can experience each prototype		 Prototypes are related to the problem statement
AND Student builds out three initial prototypes with clear 6 word headlines
OR a user can experience each prototype		 Prototypes are not related to the problem statement
AND Student does not build out three initial prototypes with clear 6 word headlines
AND a user cannot experience each prototype
TEST
Understands the user’s experience with each prototype, what the user liked, did not like, and why
AND Created a clear testing protocol and methods for tracking data		 Understands the user’s experience with each prototype, what the user liked, did not like, and why Tested each prototype but it is not clear what, if any, insights were gained. Did not test the prototypes
REFINE
Takes feedback from the client into consideration
AND Demonstrates a clear progression from the initial prototypes to the final prototype		 Takes feedback from the client into consideration
AND Demonstrates a clear progression from the prototypes to the final prototype		 Takes feedback from the client into consideration
BUT Does not demonstrate clear progression from the prototypes to the final prototype		 Did not take client feedback into consideration for their end prototype
AND Does not demonstrate clear progression from the prototypes to the final prototype
name: Dream job prototype (GRADED ASSIGNMENT)

description:
An After Action Review (AAR) is a structured review process used in many organizations. Getting used to this practice now will serve you well in your future workplace.

AARs are conducted after the completion of an event or project to reflect back on intended outcomes, actual results, what actions led to those results, and what can be improved. When done properly, an AAR is not a trial or competition where people are judged for their success or failure, but rather a healthy learning process where everyone seeks to improve how they do things, as individuals and as teams.

Conducting AARs regularly helps organizations build a culture focused on results, reflection, continuous improvement, and accountability.

How to complete your AAR:

Complete the AAR template before your next Learning Lab by reflecting on your overall performance; this includes online pre-work and assignments, Learning Labs, and with your peers. Use the AAR template, below.

AAR Template

The five parts of the AAR are organized as follows:

  1. What was expected to happen?
  2. What actually happened? 
  3. What went well, and why? 
  4. What could be improved, and how? 
  5. What immediate 

The first part has been filled out for you since what was expected to happen is the same for all Braven Fellows. You will be expected to complete the other four parts, reflecting on your own actions and progress thus far. Once you complete this form, submit it online as an assignment.

how you will be graded

After Action Review (AAR) Rubric

Skill: Learning and Continuously Improving

Indicates clear next and actionable steps resulting from reflection

10 points 9 points 8 points 7 points
Exceeds Meets expectation Somewhat meets Developing
indicates understanding of what was expected to happen and what actually happened

AND

Focuses on best-self examples

Goals and/or desired outcomes AND Results (actual outcomes) Are clear and objective

AND

Focuses on best-self examples

Goals and/or desired outcomes OR Results (actual outcomes) Are clear and objective

AND

Focuses on best-self examples

 None of the criteria in “meets” is true
Demonstrates ability to reflect on successes

All of the criteria in “meets” is true AND Reflections help build a clear arc of the overall experience AND Goes above and beyond expectations

In the “what went well and why” section, the Fellow includes: At least three to five successes (what went well) AND Connects them to reasonable causes (why)

Either: Successes and causes are articulated but not clearly or reasonable OR Only successes OR causes were described

None of the criteria in “meets” is true
Demonstrates ability to reflect on failures
All of the criteria in “meets” is true AND Reflections help build a clear arc of the overall experience AND Goes above and beyond expectations In the “what could be improved and how” section, the Fellow includes: At least three to five areas for improvement AND Recommends methods for each Either: Areas for improvement and methods are articulated but not clear or reasonable OR Only areas for improvement OR methods were described None of the criteria in “meets” is true
Indicates clear next and actionable steps resulting from reflection
Very true True Somewhat true Not true
name: After Action Review - Weeks 1-4 (GRADED ASSIGNMENT)

description:
Please submit your written Reflected Best Self Portrait here. Make sure to bring a copy to the next Learning Lab (Learning Lab 4: Setting Big Goals).

Reminders:

  • Limit to one page.
  • Collect sufficient and diverse feedback, including your own best self stories.
  • Surface patterns and themes of yourself at your best.
  • This Best Self Portrait should be something a future manager could read and determine your fit on a team. However, it shouldn't just portray things you do well but themes should reflect your identity as a human being.
  • You should feel confident that this is an accurate and clear portrayal of you at your best. 
  • For the purposes of this course, please submit a written Best Self Portrait. 

Remember to use the following naming convention for the assignment you submit: Firstname.Lastname_Assignmentname (E.g., Susie.Song_ActionPlan)

How you will be graded

BEST SELF PORTRAIT RUBRIC

Skill: Leverage personal assets and sense of self

The following rubric will be used to assess your sense of self as a leader. 

10 points 9 points 8 points 7 points
Exceeds Meets expectation Somewhat meets Developing
PORTRAIT IDENTIFIES LEADERSHIP THEMES WITH SPECIFIC EXAMPLES TO SUPPORT THESE THEMES. 

Uses at least 12 experiences (actions, contributions, attitudes) to help support leadership themes

AND

Focuses on best-self examples

Uses at least 10 experiences (actions, contributions, attitudes) to help support leadership themes

AND

Focuses on best-self examples

Uses at least 7 experiences (actions, contributions, attitudes) to help support leadership themes

AND

Focuses on best-self examples

 Uses at least 4 experiences to help support leadership themes

OR

Does not focus on best-self examples
PORTRAIT EXPLORES EMERGING THEMES ABOUT THE FELLOW'S LEADERSHIP.

States and supports at least 5 leadership themes/assets that makes them indispensible to any team

AND

Compares initial notions of leadership with post-reflection notions

States and supports at least 4 leadership themes/assets that makes them indispensible to any team

AND

Compares initial notions of leadership with post-reflection notions

States and supports at least 3 leadership themes/assets that makes them indispensible to any team 

AND

Compares initial notions of leadership with post-reflection notions

States and supports at least 2 or fewer leadership themes/assets that makes them indispensible to any team 

AND

Compares initial notions of leadership with post-reflection notions 
PORTRAIT REFLECTS GREATER CONFIDENCE IN THE FELLOW'S LEADERSHIP ABILITY. 
Very true True Somewhat true Not true
name: Written Reflected Best Self Portrait (GRADED ASSIGNMENT)

description:
It's time for your second After Action Review. 

An After Action Review (AAR) is a structured review process used in many organizations. Getting used to this practice now will serve you well in your future workplace.

AARs are conducted after the completion of an event or project to reflect back on intended outcomes, actual results, what actions led to those results, and what can be improved. When done properly, an AAR is not a trial or competition where people are judged for their success or failure, but rather a healthy learning process where everyone seeks to improve how they do things, as individuals and as teams.

Conducting AARs regularly helps organizations build a culture focused on results, reflection, continuous improvement, and accountability.

How to complete your AAR:

Complete the AAR template before your next Learning Lab by reflecting on your overall performance between Learning Labs 5-8; this includes online pre-work and assignments, Learning Labs, and with your peers. Use the AAR template, below.

AAR Template

The five parts of the AAR are organized as follows:

  1. What was expected to happen?
  2. What actually happened? 
  3. What went well, and why? 
  4. What could be improved, and how? 
  5. What immediate next steps will you take based on this reflection?

The first part has been filled out for you since what was expected to happen is the same for all Braven Fellows. You will be expected to complete the other four parts, reflecting on your own actions and progress thus far. Once you complete this form, submit it online as an assignment.

how you will be graded

Skill: Learning and Continuously Improving

Indicates clear next and actionable steps resulting from reflection

10 points 9 points 8 points 7 points
Exceeds Meets expectation Somewhat meets Developing

AND

 None of the criteria in “meets” is true
Demonstrates ability to reflect on successes

All of the criteria in “meets” is true AND Reflections help build a clear arc of the overall experience AND Goes above and beyond expectations

In the “what went well and why” section, the Fellow includes: At least three to five successes (what went well) AND Connects them to reasonable causes (why)

Either: Successes and causes are articulated but not clearly or reasonable OR Only successes OR causes were described

None of the criteria in “meets” is true
Demonstrates ability to reflect on failures
All of the criteria in “meets” is true AND Reflections help build a clear arc of the overall experience AND Goes above and beyond expectations In the “what could be improved and how” section, the Fellow includes: At least three to five areas for improvement AND Recommends methods for each Either: Areas for improvement and methods are articulated but not clear or reasonable OR Only areas for improvement OR methods were described None of the criteria in “meets” is true

description:
Make any refinements to your cover letter that incorporates the feedback from your peers, lessons learned from the Learning Lab, and customizations for the specific role or opportunity. 

How you will be graded

The following rubric will be used to assess your resume:

10 POINTS 9 POINTS 8 POINTS 7 POINTS
EXCEEDS MEETS EXPECTATION SOMEWHAT MEETS DEVELOPING
function

All of meets

AND

Communicates enthusiasm for the job

.

AND

Addresses a particular person

AND

Introduces purpose of the letter in the opening sentence

AND

Does not address a particular person

OR

Does not introduce purpose of the letter in the opening sentence

Audience and purpose are not clear

AND

AND

Does not introduce purpose of the letter in the opening sentence
form and content

All of meets

AND

Letter requires no revision

Format of the letter is clear and consistent, and demonstrates professionalism.

AND

Includes all of the 6 required elements: header, salutation, opener, body, closing, signature

AND

Letter requires little revision. Revisions that are necessary do not diminish the perception of the candidate.

AND

“I” is used minimally to start sentences and connected to aspects of the job/company.

AND

Skills are connected to job expectations

Format of the letter is somewhat clear, consistent, and professional.

AND

Includes 6 required elements: header, salutation, opener, body, closing, signature

AND

Letter requires some revision.

AND

Half the sentences start with I and skills sometimes do not connect to job expectations (e.g., I have great interpersonal skills)

Format is hard to see or irregular, and therefore not professional.

AND

Includes less than 5 required elements: header, salutation, opener, body, closing, signature

AND

Letter requires significant revision.

AND

The majority of sentences start with I and skills are usually not connected to job expectations
grammar and mechanics

No errors in spelling, grammar, or tense

A couple of minor spelling, grammar, or tense errors are present, but readability is not impacted

Some errors in spelling, grammar, and tense but still fairly readable

Numerous errors in spelling, grammar, and tense which make the letter hard to read
name: Cover letter (GRADED ASSIGNMENT)

description:
There are two parts to this assignment, due before the next Learning Lab. The purpose is to 1) build your online presence through your LinkedIn profile and 2) build your network. 

Part 1: Create a LinkedIn profile and submit the link before the next Learning Lab.  

Part 2: Have at least 30 connections on LinkedIn.

Make sure when submitting the URL to your LinkedIn Profile that your settings are set to public so that the grader can view your profile.

Refer back to this page for additional guidance and resources: here

HOW YOU WILL BE GRADED

LINKEDIN PROFILE RUBRIC

Skill: Communicating effectively when presenting yourself (written)
